quiz_title: Directive Principles - Government's Good Deeds Quiz
description: Child-friendly quiz about how the government should help all people live well
topics_covered: Free lawyers for those who need help
Same basic rules for all Indians

questions.question: Ravi's family doesn't have enough money for a lawyer when they need legal help. Which Directive Principle says the government should help them?
options: Free legal aid for everyone
Free food for everyone
Free houses for everyone
Free clothes for everyone
questions.correct_answer: Free legal aid for everyone
questions.explanation: Article 39A says the government should provide free legal help to people who cannot afford lawyers, just like how schools provide free books to students who need them!
questions.child_friendly_analogy: Like how teachers help students who are struggling with homework, the government should help people who are struggling with legal problems.

questions.question: In Priya's village, some children cannot go to school because their families need them to work. What should the government do according to Directive Principles?
options: Ignore the problem
Make sure all children can go to school and families have enough support
Only help rich families
Let children decide for themselves
questions.correct_answer: Make sure all children can go to school and families have enough support
questions.explanation: Directive Principles tell the government to ensure everyone has good living conditions - this means children should be in school, not working to support their families!
questions.child_friendly_analogy: Like how parents make sure all their children get food and education, the government should make sure all Indian families have what they need.

questions.question: The government should try to give good jobs to all adults who want to work.
questions.explanation: Yes! Article 41 says the government should try to provide work opportunities for everyone, just like how a good school tries to help every student find their talents!
questions.child_friendly_analogy: Like how a coach tries to find the right position for every player on the team, the government should help every person find good work.

questions.question: Asha's friend says people from different religions should follow completely different laws. What do Directive Principles suggest?
options: Every religion should have different laws
Only one religion should make laws
The government should work toward having the same basic rules for all Indians
Laws should change every day
questions.correct_answer: The government should work toward having the same basic rules for all Indians
questions.explanation: Article 44 talks about a Uniform Civil Code - this means working toward having the same basic fair rules for all Indians, while still respecting everyone's beliefs!
questions.child_friendly_analogy: Like how all students in a school follow the same basic rules (no bullying, be respectful) while still celebrating their different cultures and traditions.

questions.question: In your city, many old people don't have anyone to take care of them. According to Directive Principles, what should the government do?
options: Nothing - it's not their problem
Help create programs to take care of elderly people
Tell families to handle it themselves
Only help rich elderly people
questions.correct_answer: Help create programs to take care of elderly people
questions.explanation: Directive Principles say the government should help ensure everyone can live with dignity - this includes taking care of elderly people who need support!
questions.child_friendly_analogy: Like how good friends help each other when someone is in trouble, the government should help citizens who need support.

questions.question: Directive Principles are like the government's _______ list of good things to do for all people.
questions.correct_answer: homework
questions.explanation: Directive Principles are like homework assignments for the government - they tell the government what good things it should try to do to help all people live better lives!
questions.child_friendly_analogy: Just like students get homework to help them learn and grow, the government gets 'homework' from the Constitution to help all citizens live well.

questions.question: Meera lives in a remote village where there is no school. What should happen according to Directive Principles?
options: Meera should move to the city
The government should help provide education in her village
Only boys need schools
Education is not important
questions.correct_answer: The government should help provide education in her village
questions.explanation: Article 45 originally said the government should provide free education for all children. Now it's a Fundamental Right, but Directive Principles still guide making education accessible everywhere!
questions.child_friendly_analogy: Like how parents try to give all their children the same opportunities, the government should try to give all children access to good education.

questions.question: In Raj's neighborhood, many people get sick because the water is not clean. What does the government's 'homework' (Directive Principles) say about this?
options: People should buy their own water purifiers
Only rich areas deserve clean water
The government should work to provide clean water and healthcare for everyone
Sick people should move somewhere else
questions.correct_answer: The government should work to provide clean water and healthcare for everyone
questions.explanation: Article 47 says the government should work to improve public health and provide clean living conditions for everyone - clean water is part of this!
questions.child_friendly_analogy: Like how a good school provides clean drinking water for all students, the government should ensure all neighborhoods have clean water.

questions.question: The government should make sure that a few very rich people don't control everything while everyone else stays poor.
questions.explanation: Article 39 says wealth should be distributed fairly so everyone has a chance at a good life, not concentrated in just a few hands!
questions.child_friendly_analogy: Like how a good teacher makes sure all students get a chance to participate and learn, not just the few who raise their hands first.

questions.question: Sara notices that in some places, women don't get paid the same as men for doing the same work. What do Directive Principles say about this?
options: Men should always earn more
Women should do different jobs
Equal pay for equal work for both men and women
Only women should work
questions.correct_answer: Equal pay for equal work for both men and women
questions.explanation: Article 39(d) says there should be equal pay for equal work for both men and women - fairness means same work, same pay!
questions.child_friendly_analogy: Like how all students who score the same marks get the same grade regardless of whether they're boys or girls, workers should get equal pay for equal work.

questions.question: The factory near Amit's school is polluting the river where children play. According to Directive Principles, what should the government do?
options: Let the factory continue polluting
Tell children to play somewhere else
Protect the environment and people's health
Close all factories
questions.correct_answer: Protect the environment and people's health
questions.explanation: Article 48A says the government should protect and improve the environment - this includes keeping rivers clean for everyone's health and happiness!
questions.child_friendly_analogy: Like how a good gardener takes care of plants and keeps the garden clean, the government should take care of our environment.

questions.question: Article 51 says India should promote _______ and peaceful solutions when countries have disagreements.
questions.correct_answer: peace
questions.explanation: Just like how children should solve problems by talking rather than fighting, India should help countries solve their problems peacefully!
questions.child_friendly_analogy: Like how good friends help other friends solve their arguments without fighting, India should help countries be peaceful with each other.

questions.question: In Kavya's town, some children from certain backgrounds are not allowed to use the public playground. What should the government do according to Directive Principles?
options: Build separate playgrounds for different groups
Ensure all children can use public facilities equally
Let the community decide who can play
Close the playground
questions.correct_answer: Ensure all children can use public facilities equally
questions.explanation: Directive Principles support social justice - this means making sure everyone gets fair treatment and access to public facilities, regardless of their background!
questions.child_friendly_analogy: Like how all students in a school can use the library and playground equally, all citizens should be able to use public facilities equally.

questions.question: According to Directive Principles, workers should have safe working conditions and fair treatment.
questions.explanation: Articles 39, 41, and 43 talk about ensuring workers have decent working conditions, fair wages, and protection - just like how students deserve a safe, supportive learning environment!
questions.child_friendly_analogy: Like how schools should provide safe classrooms and fair treatment for students, workplaces should be safe and fair for workers.

questions.question: Pooja's village doesn't have proper roads, electricity, or internet. What do Directive Principles suggest the government should do?
options: Focus only on big cities
Tell villagers to move to cities
Work to develop rural areas with basic facilities
Villages don't need development
questions.correct_answer: Work to develop rural areas with basic facilities
questions.explanation: Directive Principles emphasize improving living standards for everyone, including people in villages - everyone deserves access to basic facilities for a good life!
questions.child_friendly_analogy: Like how a good principal works to improve all classrooms in the school, not just the fancy ones, the government should work to improve all areas of the country.

questions.question: Why are Directive Principles called the government's 'homework'?
options: Because they are optional and can be ignored
Because they are goals the government should work toward to help all people
Because only teachers need to follow them
Because they change every day
questions.correct_answer: Because they are goals the government should work toward to help all people
questions.explanation: Directive Principles are like homework because they give the government important goals to work toward - making sure everyone in India can live a good, dignified life!
questions.child_friendly_analogy: Just like homework helps students learn and improve, Directive Principles help the government learn how to better serve all citizens.

questions.question: The government should protect India's historical monuments and cultural treasures for future generations.
questions.explanation: Article 49 says the government should protect monuments and places of cultural importance - like taking care of family heirlooms so future generations can enjoy them too!
questions.child_friendly_analogy: Like how families preserve old photos and special items for children and grandchildren, the government should preserve India's cultural treasures.

questions.question: Dev sees that stray animals in his area are not being treated well. What do Directive Principles say about this?
options: Animals are not the government's concern
Only pet animals should be protected
The government should ensure compassion toward all living creatures
People can treat animals however they want
questions.correct_answer: The government should ensure compassion toward all living creatures
questions.explanation: Article 48A includes showing compassion to all living creatures - this means treating animals kindly and protecting them from cruelty!
questions.child_friendly_analogy: Like how kind children are gentle with pets and help animals in need, our whole society should be compassionate toward animals.

questions.question: Article 51A(h) encourages developing _______ temper and scientific thinking among people.
questions.correct_answer: scientific
questions.explanation: This means encouraging people to think logically, ask questions, and use evidence to make decisions - just like how students learn to think critically in school!
questions.child_friendly_analogy: Like how good students learn to ask 'why' and 'how' and look for evidence, all Indians should develop the habit of scientific thinking.

questions.question: Anita's community wants to start a cooperative store where everyone shares profits equally. How do Directive Principles view this?
options: Cooperation is discouraged
Only big companies should exist
Cooperative enterprises should be promoted for community benefit
Individual competition is the only way
questions.correct_answer: Cooperative enterprises should be promoted for community benefit
questions.explanation: Article 43B encourages cooperative societies - when people work together and share benefits fairly, it helps build a better community for everyone!
questions.child_friendly_analogy: Like how students work together on group projects and share the success, communities can work together in cooperatives and share the benefits.

questions.question: Many children in Rekha's school come without proper breakfast and look weak. What should the government do according to Directive Principles?
options: Tell parents to feed their children better
Ignore the problem
Work to improve nutrition levels and provide support where needed
Only help children from certain families
questions.correct_answer: Work to improve nutrition levels and provide support where needed
questions.explanation: Article 47 talks about improving nutrition levels - this includes making sure children get proper food for healthy growth and learning!
questions.child_friendly_analogy: Like how a caring coach makes sure all team members are well-fed and healthy to play their best, the government should ensure all children are well-nourished to learn and grow.

questions.question: According to Directive Principles, the government should work to reduce the use of harmful substances like alcohol and drugs.
questions.explanation: Article 47 mentions prohibiting harmful substances - the government should work to protect people's health by reducing things that can harm communities!
questions.child_friendly_analogy: Like how schools have rules against bringing harmful things that could hurt students, the government should work to reduce harmful substances in society.

questions.question: Grandmother Lakshmi makes beautiful pottery at home and wants to sell it to support her family. How do Directive Principles support this?
options: Only big factories should make things
Home businesses are not important
Cottage industries and village crafts should be promoted
Old people shouldn't work
questions.correct_answer: Cottage industries and village crafts should be promoted
questions.explanation: Article 43 encourages promoting cottage industries - this means supporting people like Grandmother Lakshmi who make things at home or in small workshops!
questions.child_friendly_analogy: Like how schools encourage students' individual talents and hobbies, the government should encourage people's home businesses and traditional crafts.

questions.question: Uncle Mohan got injured at work and cannot earn money for his family. What do Directive Principles suggest should happen?
options: He should find a new job immediately
His family should manage on their own
There should be social security support for workers who get injured
Only rich people deserve help when injured
questions.correct_answer: There should be social security support for workers who get injured
questions.explanation: Article 41 talks about providing work, education, and public assistance in case of unemployment, old age, sickness, and disability - like having insurance to help when bad things happen!
questions.child_friendly_analogy: Like how good friends help each other when someone is hurt or in trouble, society should have systems to help people who face difficulties.

questions.question: Directive Principles guide the government to create a _______ state where everyone can live with dignity and opportunity.
questions.correct_answer: welfare
questions.explanation: A welfare state means a country where the government actively works to ensure all citizens have good living conditions, opportunities, and support when they need it!
questions.child_friendly_analogy: Like how a caring family looks after all its members and makes sure everyone has what they need, a welfare state looks after all its citizens.
